Source: The World Bank: Central Microdata Catalog
Description: This database consists of national living standards and health surveys, including access to the surveys used.

This is a database of survey data by country. The surveys are based on a set of model questionnaires, but are modified for each country and therefore are not identical. A description of this data is available here

9051 datasets from the International Household Survey Network with data for most countries in the world. Datasets include census information, agriculture, energy use, pesticide use, household consumption, and much more. If you are looking for data in a developing country then IHSN is a good place to start.

Source: Social and Economic Well-being (RAND) (Indonesians, Malaysians, and Guatemalans)
Description: Family Life Survey for Indonesians, Malaysians, and Guatemalans.
Longitudinal, multithematic survey representative of the Mexican population at the national, urban, rural, and regional level. Data has been collected in three rounds: 2002, 2005-2006, and 2009-2012.

Source: International Fertilizer Association Fertilizer Use by Crop
Description: This data set contains fertilizer use by crop in the main fertilizer-consuming countries. The data covers 27 countries and the EU-27, which accounts for 94% of global fertilizer consumption.
This computer program enables the calculation of crop water requirements and irrigation requirements based on soil, climate and crop data.

Source: Water Footprint Network Water Footprint Statistics
Description: This data set contains estimates for green, blue and grey water footprints of crops, derived crop products, biofuels, livestock products, and industrial products. All data are available at national and sub-national level.

Source: United States Department of Agriculture Economic Research Service: Commodity and Food Elasticities
Description: This database consists of information and estimates on price and income elasticities for agricultural products. Most of the demand elasticities in this data product are from academic and government research conducted in the United States on consumer demand, as published in working papers, dissertations, and peer-reviewed journals and as presented at professional conferences in the United States. The most fully covered countries are the United States and China, and the greatest number of demand studies are for vegetables, fruits, and grocery products such as coffee and ketchup.

This database provides population data and projections for each country from 1950–2100 and food production, food trade, and agriculture-related resource use data for 1961–2014. There is also a suite of food security indices. In order to provide complete spatial and temporal coverage, some data provided is interpolated or modeled. One should pay close attention to the documentation before proceeding with an analysis.

Source: Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) Fisheries and Aquaculture Department: FishStatJ
Description: This database consists of productions and trade data in terms of price and quantity by country for 1950–2012. FishStat allows for multiple species and commodity grouping schemes to facilitate matching across data sources. It should be noted though that there is not complete consistency between the production by source and production and trade data sets.
This database contains agricultural production, agricultural environmental accounts, and economic accounts for EU nations.
Twenty years of satellite data for maize (corn) and soybean crops throughout the Midwestern United States.

U.S. agricultural information from 1850 to current with animal & products, crops, demographics, economics, and environmental. Various geographic levels are available depending on the variable of interest.
Estimated pesticide use from 1992 to 2019 at the state-level crop group.

Source: USGS Nitrogen and Phosphorus from Fertilizer
Description: County-level nitrogen and phosphorus from fertilizer and manure from 1950 to 2017 in conterminous U.S. Estimates are by kilograms of nitrogen and phosphorus.

The forestry database has information on harvests, replanting, fires, forest insects, pest control, revenue, stock of wood. Data is available at the national and provincial level and is available for varying years depending on the dataset (usually 1990-2019).
Hundreds of datasets for a wide variety of variables available for different years. They have raster data, data sets, and models.
Data for global and national level statistics of forest cover, land cover, forest change, fires, and climate for every country. Data is from 2001 onwards.
Data sets are posted by year and each file contains the forestry information for each state. Data is from 2000 to 2016 with additional information from 1992.

A detailed catalog of data from the OECD countries on Agriculture and Fisheries, Demography and Population, Development, Economic Projections, Education and Training, Environment (Air and Climate, Water, Waste, Forests, Environmental Policy (Fossil Fuel Subsidies and taxes)...), Finance, Globalization, Health, Industry, Communication Abilities, International Trade, Labour, National Accounts, Economic Indicators, Productivity, Prices and PPP, Taxation and Regulation, Transportation, and more. Each category has subcategories. The data is easily downloadable and viewable within the website.

Data on poverty, disease, hunger, climate change, war, existential risks, and inequality (and dozens of other topics. They write many articles on many different topics and are a trusted source of data for the top universities and news outlets around the world.
A global research organization that focuses on Food, Forests, Water, Energy, Climate, the Ocean and Cities. Hundreds of data sets on many environmental and natural resource topics.

A well organized dataset search site for data in the US and Canada for many economic sectors and socioeconomic data. The website is aimed towards poverty data but there is substantial overlap with environmental data.

Locating spatial data and information available through Internet servers or GIS data clearinghouses. Data include Climate Change Scenarios, Extreme Heat Climate maps, and other Climate data. The website also has useful tutorials on learning how GIS works.

Similar to the GIS data from the GIS Socioeconomic Data but with global information for air quality, nighttime light, water quality, biological diversity, and socioeconomic data. This is an excellent source to verify reported data from other sources. The Data Pathfinder is extremely useful to find data on specific questions like Health and Air Quality Data, Biological Diversity and Ecological Forecasting Data, and Agriculture and Water Resources data.

Datasets and Reports on pollution data in the USA for pollution (Air quality, hazardous waste, non-attainment areas, clear air Markets and more). The website has useful information on regulations, policies, criteria, and goals from the EPA.

The EPA has data on precipitation (don't use rain as an instrument), US temperature, basin boundaries, glaciers, heat-related hospitalizations, unusual temperatures in each region, environmental justice, and more. The data is available at the national and some regional levels. The website is mostly descriptive and some data sources may be hosted on other websites or through other agencies.
Statistics Canada provides hundreds of datasets on various socioeconomic and environmental datasets. Data can be searched for by geography, frequency, subject, and by survey.

Natural Resources stores data and maps of Canada for various environmental variables. There is substantial overlap with Statistics Canada but more datasets relating to industry effects on the environment, Nature, Parks, and more.
Dozens of datasets that cover 500,000 villages in India and 8000 towns for over 25 years. Data variables are predominately socioeconomic data.

Meta (Facebook) data that can be used to track populations, population density, mobility, connections, electrical and network coverage, economic poverty, business trends, other information collected by Meta. The data for climate conversations and CrowdTangle can be used to analyze public discussion on climate change, environmentalism, and economics.

A site that helps you navigate other dataset sites and helps find datasets for machine learning. There are many sites listed, some of which are environmental and/or economics related. Importantly, this website can help you learn how to do machine learning which you may apply to other situations.
Google Search for datasets with filters on what type of dataset, topics, format, usage rights, and updated information date.
A brief and non-exhaustive catalog of Canadian data sources.

Source: Plamen Nikolov's Useful Datasets for Development Economics Research
Description: A detailed list of micro and macro datasets for international, US, and UK data. Each dataset listed is described with Regions, data type (usually panel) and a 1 sentence description of the data available.

Source: Yale Law - 75 Sources of Economic Data
Description: A website that looks much like this one with 75 links. The links are mostly to US department and Bureau websites for the US data with the addition of a few international sites. This site is may be useful if you are looking for environmental laws or regulations in the US.

Source: Data in Economic History (Giuliano and Matranga 2020)
Description: A working paper that methodically explains where and how to find historical data for economics. From the abstract "I...[W]e provide a comprehensive analysis of the types of historical data most commonly used in economic research and discuss a variety of issues that they raise, such as the constant change in national and administrative borders; the reshuffling of ethnic groups due to migration, colonialism, natural disasters, and many other forces. We also point out which methodological advances allow economists to overcome or minimize these problems." If you are can not find data and are unsure of where it might be, this article is worth reading.

Source: Our World in Data Electricity Generation
Description: Data from 1985 to 2021 on country and continent energy production for every country in the world. Our World in Data also has the cost of renewable energy, renewable energy by country, renewable energy produced by source, and many other data sets on energy.
U.S. electricity generation data by source from 1950 to 2020.
Hourly electricity production data for each state by electricity source. Data is available from 2018-2022.

This database estimates marine extractions for each country from 1950–present. The data can be disaggregated by industrial, artisanal, recreational, or subsistence sectors, by taxon, and by reported vs. unreported.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) maintains US fisheries landings and trade statistics. Additional US trade data is available through the US Census data portal.

Source: UN Food and Agriculture: Fisheries and Aquaculture
Description: Global statistics on aquaculture production, fishing capture, number of fishers, as well as data specific the regions such as Eastern Central Atlantic, Mediterranean, Southeast Atlantic, and others.
Data for Canadian weather from 1840 to 2022. Data is available at the Provincial level by weather station. Monthly normals, averages, and extremes are available from 1940 to 2010.
U.S. local (land based) and global (coastal, oceanographic, geophysical, and climate) data for normals, temperature, precipitation. Data is available from 1901 to 2022 for many datasets.

This dataset provides near-surface meteorological data for driving land surface models and other terrestrial modeling systems. It blends reanalysis data with observations and disaggregates in time and space. The dataset is currently available at 1.0 degree (plus 0.5 and 0.25 degree), 3-hourly (plus daily and monthly) resolution globally for 1948-2008. Experimental updates include a 1901-2012 version (that will become V2), real-time updates, higher resolution versions for Africa (that assimilates all available gauge data) and future climate projections based on bias-corrected climate model output.

The datasets presented here have been divided into three categories: Output data, Source data, and Intermediate data. Data is available from 1750 for monthly land, 1833 for high and low temperature, and 1850 for monthly land+ ocean.
Global climate layers (gridded climate data) with a spatial resolution of about 1 km.
A mix of processed and raw files, includes historical (gridded) data and projections.
Air quality and particulate levels from BC monitoring stations across the province. Some datasets are over 2 GB to use and may be difficult or time consuming to open or clean.
Data on particulates, pollution, wind direction, lead and more from 1980.

Source: US EPA Air Markets Program Data
Description: Emissions data by month, quarter, allowance transactions, allowance holdings, compliance, and SMOKE data from 1995 onwards.

Air quality data from 1969 (very limited), 1976 (somewhat limited) and 1990 (complete) onwards. Filtering by country, city, area, pollution type, year, pollution level are available. There is also a working map viewer (many other sites have them that do not work or barely work).
High quality and very small area data for each London borough's air quality from 2006.
2014-2018 data on hot-spot zones in the US for cancer-causing industrial air pollution.

Source: Canada National Long-term Water Quality Monitoring Data
Description: Various major water bodies in Canada pollution data from 2000 onwards.
Water quality data from 1995 onwards for river, lake, and coastal water pollution and quality data. Data is available through data sets and GIS shapefiles.

Global GIS data and time series data for all administrative areas and basins level 6. This dataset tracks all long-term changes in water-related ecosystems. This is an excellent resource. Data is for 1984-2019.

A Knowledgebase providing single chemical environmental toxicity data on aquatic life, terrestrial plants and wildlife. They track 12,485 chemicals across 13,709 species (plants and animals). Database has an excellent search function.
Lists of various models for the effects of pesticides, ECOTOX data, chemical properties, biodiversity, health from pesticides, and much more.
762 coastal areas impacted by eutrophication and/or hypoxia. Data is global and spans many decades depending on the country and site.
68,121 datasets on biodiversity on Global and local biodiversity.

Source: Biological Diversity and Ecological Forecasting Data (NASA)
Description: Forecasts for various climate change, ecological, biodiversity, water quality, green house gases, and other data available in data sets and GIS data.
Data on migratory birds for various years in various regions of the U.S.
Breeding Bird data for the U.S. and Canada for over 400 bird species from the 1960s onward.

Global database of various time series for quantifying and understanding biodiversity change. Diversity in marine, terrestrial, and freshwater realms. There are hundreds of studies and millions of records.
Geophysical, Meteorological, Extreme Temperature, Hydrological, Climatological, Biological, Extraterrestrial (Space weather), Industrial accidents, transport accidents.
Hurricanes and cyclones in the US from 1958 onwards

The Administration and Data Entry module is a relational and structural database through which the database is fed by filling in predefined fields (space and temporal data, types of events and causes, sources) and by both direct and indirect effects (deaths, houses, infrastructure, economic sectors). The Analysis module allows access to the database by queries that may include relations among the diverse variables of effects, types of events, causes, sites, dates, etc. This module allows at the same time to represent those queries with tables, graphics and thematic maps. Data is mostly for developing countries and has a wide range of periods available depending on the country of interest.
Earthquakes in Canada from the 16th century onwards
U.S. earthquake from 1995 onwards and earthquake scenarios. Other data is available. More data may be available elsewhere on US earthquakes.

Source: Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research(Open ICPSR)
Description: Survey data on beliefs from 2008 onwards on Energy and the Environment in the U.S.
Surveys conducted biennially from 2004-2020 in countries without their own survey (Not for OECD or Eurostat countries).
Time-varying, spatial natural resource dataset that covers 197 resources in 116 countries (predominantly developing countries). Data starts in 1988 in some locations.

Source: EPA Facts and Figures on Materials, Wastes and Recycling
Description: Reports on Waste, recycling, composting, food waste, landfills, electronic waste, and others at the state or county level depending on the dataset and from 1960-2018 depending on the variable.

Resources on the state of Canadians' health, including statistics, facts, reports and data. Data sets include exposure to chemicals, heavy metals, and other content related to environmental factors. Data is available for a different number of years for different datasets.
Various data sets for health outcomes in the U.S. for a wide variety of health outcomes. Period of data availability ranges by dataset.

Source: Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME): Global Health Data Exchange (GHDx)
Description: This data set provides estimates for health and demographic data using Bayesian models which are informed by a range of researcher, government, and NGO data. The estimates include uncertainty and the code generating the estimates is available. Among other estimates, the database contains estimates of deaths by cause (including protein-energy malnutrition, iodine deficiency, iron-deficiency anemia, and other nutritional deficiencies). There is good documentation for the estimates, but one must be careful to know what data went into the models so as not to test an effect when non-independent data were used in the estimate. The article describing the data includes a supplementary file detailing the estimation methods and can be found here.

Database with subnational estimates of child malnutrition (prevalence for stunting, underweight, overweight, wasting and severe wasting indicators) using available data up to 2012. Data can be accessed using an API. These statistics by quintile are available in the World Bank: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth.
The WHO Mortality Database is a compilation of mortality data by age, sex and cause of death, as reported annually by Member States from their civil registration systems.
A huge number of data sets for nearly anything economic related for most countries in the world.

Source: United States Department of Labor: Bureau of Labor Statistics
Description: This database consists of economic data for the United States, including data on on inflation, prices, and time use.

This global supply chain database consists of a multi-region input-output table with matching environmental and social satellite accounts for 190 countries. The database includes over 15,000 sectors for 1990-2015 and a range of environmental indicators, including GHG emissions, air pollution, energy use, water requirements, land occupation and N and P emissions.

Source: The World Bank: Global Consumption Database
Description: This database consists of data on household consumption patterns in developing countries based on household surveys. Four levels of consumption are used to segment the market in each country: lowest, low, middle, and higher. They are based on global income distribution data, which rank the global population by income per capita. More details on the data can be found here.
This database includes a range of economic data for the US, including GDP, employment by industry, price indices, and international trade.

This data is maintained by the United Nations and consists of reported bilateral trade data (annually and monthly) for commodities (using HS codes). This data is publicly available when accessing a limited number of records. A subscription allows bulk downloads and access to a derived data product produced by CEPII, the BACI trade data.
India Landcover classification for Indian cities using data from the European Space Agency. Data from 1992-2020 for 132 non-attainment cities.

CFS has undertaken through a partnership between the Census Bureau and the Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) is conducted every 5 years as part of the Economic Census. The CFS produces data on the movement of goods in the United States. It provides information on commodities shipped, their value, weight, and mode of transportation, as well as the origin and destination of shipments of commodities from manufacturing, mining, wholesale, and selected retail and services establishments.
Institutional and electoral results data for political economy for 180 countries from 1975-2020
Harvard's Dataverse hosts policy information that diffuses across U.S. states. It contains 4 datasets which have policies from 1691, 1912, or 1960 onwards.

198 national jurisdictions and 98 sub-national jurisdictions (50 U.S. States, 13 Canadian Provinces and Territories, Japanese Municipalities, 32 Chinese Provinces and Municipalities from 1990 to 2018.

Source: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC): Climate Change Projection data
Description: The IPCC produces several projections for climate change scenarios for socioeconomic data based on different potential scenarios.
European country statistics on waste production, waste management, recycling, and management of hazardous waste.
Census data from 103 countries, 547 censuses and surveys, over 1 billion person records.

A collection of satellite imagery data from government satellites from various space agencies. Data can be used to track land use changes, vegetation, wildfires, weather, temperature, and several other geographic variables.

Biennial surveys provides comprehensive information about waste generated by Canadians, waste disposed and diverted from landfills, and their sources. This information is collected from businesses that provide waste management services.

US climate model projections intened for data innovators, those who want to use government data to ehlp others learn of the impacts of climate change, or make decisions in which climate change change plays a role. The large projections have been downscaled to be usable on domestic computers.
Global oil production by country from when each country began producing or tracking their production.

Type of tax, status of taxes, and juristiction of taxes for every country. 68 carbon pricing initiatives are available in 46 countries with 36 subnational jurisdictions. These initiatives cover 23% of global emissions.
Wildfire incident reports from all federal agencies, as captured in FAMWEB.
Database of U.S. state and federal EPA inspections of facility environmental air quality violations. See: Cecato (2022).
Global Historical Air Quality Data
Gridded reanalysis data (32km cells)
Gridded reanalysis data (4km cells)
Meta: Climate Data Guide
